when you mentioned different stragies... i had an idea for them to make a simulation.
Food mechanic
1 food ensures survival, while each extra food grants a 100% reproduce chance.
Areas
Lake/Ocean
Blobs here fly over, but some can fish, and some lie in wait. Only a few spawn.
Tree
Houses many animals. Useful. They are abundant.
Jay
Acts like a dove, but if it manages to share or get all the food, it goes for more food. If they get successful, they go home and have a survival chance of 100% and have as much babies as how much extra food they got. However, if the other creature is hostile the jay dies with no survival chance. Risky but rewarding.
Rooster
Struts his stuff and acts aggressive, scaring away any peaceful blob, acting like a hawk but can't win a fight, causing it to act like a dove when faced with a hostile blob.
Pelican
Waits by a lake. Any blob coming close gets all their food stolen, no matter if it is hostile. However, if it doesn't catch a blob it catches a small fish, only giving it 0.5 food
Robin
Lives in trees. Always takes the fruit pile next to it's tree. Two robins live in a tree at once. If there is a hostile trying to steal, there are 2 conditions.
1 robin: the Robin acts like a dove in this situation.
2 robins: the robins beat the hostile, killing it and 1 survives, however the other robin dies. Strength in numbers.
Woodpecker
Lives in trees, digging holes for bugs, giving it 1.5 food. It goes to other trees for bugs. If there is s bird in the tree, it gets scared away early and only gets 0.5 food.
Duck
Acts like a dove. Once it has 1 food, gains double food from all sources, making it a baby factory. They live in lakes and Pelicans are not hostile towards them. However, ducklings need food and take 1 generation to grow up, and if they don't get the sufficient food before aging and being able to gather food themselves, they die.

Simon: Hierarchies have remained constant throughout recorded civilization.

John :For perhaps the last 12,000 years, sure.

John: but you know as well as I do, before the discovery of agriculture, there was no such thing, ninety-nine percent of human
history has been egalitarian.

Simon: I said civilization, John, meandering hunter-gatherer tribes chucking spears and eating grubs isn't civilization.

John: How contemporacist of you, yet 20th century studies of numerous hunter-gatherer tribes, those still surviving in
remote areas just as they did thousands of years prior, actually show socially rich cultures. Adult life spans not far from ours.

John: Relatively peaceful
in balance with nature.

John: No leaders, no group hierarchy,
no inequality.

John: To argue today's society is somehow
more civilized is dubious at best.

Simon: Well, then perhaps you can encourage all your enlightened followers to come together and live out their utopian fantasy in the Amazon jungle.

John: You mean what's left of it ? what hasn't been destroyed by the supposedly advanced culture that's ravaged the natural world
into total decline in the name of infinite consumption and economic growth ?

John: and the point here, Simon, is hunter-gatherer cultures are evidence of human variability, variability which contradicts
your vague biological determinism.

Simon: John, just because history shows a range of behaviors across time doesn't prove anything.

Simon: The introduction of agriculture indeed changed the human condition because it triggered a dormant trait in our evolutionary psychology, a trait that wasn't
expressed before.

John: How ?

Simon: By the advent of economic surplus.

Simon: Resources and goods that could be stored, hoarded, stockpiled, owned, traded, controlled and
leveraged for personal gain, a phenomenon that was impossible in a hunter-gatherer reality and it was that realization that sparked our now
omnipresent drive toward dominance and hierarchy.

John: I didn't know that.

John: Genetic dormancy of an evolutionary expression, needed an environmental trigger, psychological drive, but then morphs into complex oppressive institutions
and structures.

John: Compelling. Intuitive. Plausible.

john: Too bad it's wrong

John:All simpleton, pedestrian, bio-deterministic conclusions that are nothing more than elitist projections.

John: Agriculture did change everything but not because of someone's dormant psychological drive magically triggered
by economic surplus.

John: It was about what a society technically required, dramatically shifting incentives and the very nature of human relationships.

John: Think about it.

First you need the proper land, water, the right conditions to farm, then creating settlements around those fruitful areas as opposed to foraging.

Since land quality varies some settlements will prosper due to their geography and some will falter.

So what happens when a group finds itself with failed crops and no way to survive the winter ?

They may trade with other groups, building out what we call a market today, giving way to the idea of property and so on.

Or if they have
nothing to trade, desperate, they may invade, they may steal, compete, establishing the need for protection, laws, armies, the state institution itself.

At the same time, people begin to notice the imbalance and power of this new propertied reality, rationalizing the hoarding of wealth
for the sake of future security.

Hence the birth of inequity, poverty, socio-economic class.

John: Simon, every major structural aspect of society today, from ownership to trade to nation states to institutional warfare
to the competitive ethic to vast economic inequality and power hierarchy was predictable.

Snowballing ever since.

Coming late here, I cant help but notice that its focuses on the equilibrium rather than the interesting dynamics at play within the small original population : when food sources is far sufficient, the creatures can often feed themselves without any encounter with fellow creatures. This may change the proportion between the D and H strategy at the beginning, limiting the fatal H encounters and favouring H facing D. Bear in mind that D may be more numerous in a non-hostile environment, granting the first hawks a decisive advantage.

Translating these observations to human groups, I'm tempted to infere that the relative competitiveness of each strategy during this "conquest" phase may influence their cultural prestige. Even though the advantage of H strategy has been lost through population and H/D ratio growth, its "historic" justification might lead the group to turn to such strategy rather than to update its worthiness.

We must also bear in mind that the creatures might work in groups with mixed strategies, wether basic or mixed strategies for each of them. It means that several groups might fight for food sources, each mixing strategies : truce, fight, predation, flight, ... The optimal strategy mix of a group therefore depending on the stragy mix of the surrounding groups, their respective demography and food rarity (inducing the advancement in the conquest of the territory (total demography/foof quantity)). This argument only holds if you assume that reproduction will happen between creatures rather than alone... which justifes the existence of groups who have to interbreed to keep an optimal strategy mix.

It seems that there's another layer, using real world (anecdotal) observations.
Hawk seems advantageous when resources are variable (famine, drought, etc), but include "small unit" dove (family units or cities storing resources to prepare for the next disaster), but when the social safety net is stable, the element destroying it for everyone is hoarding; there's enough food for 10, but if one or two take it all, or worse intentionally destroy it so others can't get it, then the system never really gets to a calm diplomatic stage of strong social safety net and technological specialists (a population that doesn't need to hunt, gather, farm, herd, fish).
Imposed limits (limit 1 strawberry basket per person per day is the reason we all know what they taste like even though supply is tiny and there's a short growing season) and taxes starting above the level of socal safety net, with taxes funding those who made less, with intent that they too make enough to contribute (shrinking poverty numbers).

Problem in this example is that Blobs have equal power level. In real life it's nothing like that. Mutual destruction happens when two persons are almost equally powerful. If difference is too big it's not gonna work and one of them will win in some degree. In the end it might work like each of them taking proportional food to their power or it will be war to death - all or nothing. In that case winner will have minimum amount of profit compared to peace option. Let's say if he's twice as powerful he's gonna get 1.5 from the first option, but second means he's going to lose his stamina and get injury so it's always below 1.5(let's say 1.25). Going Hawk way makes sense in personal survival, because the fact that you're ready to go for mutual destruction means that you can get better terms. If the other Hawk realizes that he might not go to risk, so he rather give up 0.5 < x < 0.75(in cases that Hawk got little bit more scared maybe even more. It's about when it becomes direct existencial threat) and win peacefully than initiate conflict. Other variable in this situation is that Hawk who just got into fight will be weakened for his future adventures compared to the other Hawks and this acts as prevention which can be used by the weaker Hawks.

The only issue with this simulation I can think of is that I feel like the benefit to aggression is undermined. Hawks vs Hawks has this mathematically integrated flaw that it's somehow beneficial to fight for food and ultimately gain nothing from it--which I can't help but feel is a bit of a senseless sentiment only there to assist the design of the equilibrium. While there are multiple variables and angles to account for in nature--wouldn't it make more sense, in a combative situation between Hawks, for one to perish and the other to walk away with 2 food pellets? I understand that, given the initial setup, this would make it so every Hawk killed guarantees another Hawk's reproduction--which is a bit of a moot formula--so maybe setting the successful Hawk's expended energy rule implementation is necessary to keep it interesting; granting the surviving Hawk <2 food pellets rather than 2. Though another issue comes to light: why play it safe and be a Dove vs Hawk situation? Initially it was due to it yielding a higher chance to survive than Hawk vs Hawk, but... with my tweek in mind, both Hawk vs Dove and Hawk vs Hawk would yield a 50% chance at survival ultimately for both example's participants (excluding the Hawk with a 100% survival guarantee in Dove vs Hawk)--the only major difference is whether the survivors walk away with 1/2 & 3/2 food pellets or 2 food pellets... one bird perishes from either hunger (if there's a single dove) or combat (if they're both hawks). Maybe boosting Dove vs Hawk's survival rates to 75% - 100% respectively would make more sense for higher survival chance at the expense of food pellet yield; reproduction/time. While Dove vs Dove is arguably still the safest option--there needs to be consideration towards the natural factor of "higher risk, higher reward"; 50% chance of survival for potentially more food pellets. Why have aggression in the first place if there's no benefit?

What I like about this is despite the simplicity, it shows that the concept of a utopia with only doves is really not possible.  Simply introduce one hawk into the mix and presto, it eventually is a mix of hawks and doves.  That is nature, the way the universe works.  Change the names slightly.  Let say the Hawks are aggressive only as they want to be fruitful and multiply.  Call them breeders.  The doves on the other hand are unwillling to be pushy in order to multiply.  So they wait for a chance.  So same result with breeders vs waiters, a fluxuating balance occurs.  Now the final step would be to increase the probability of a breeder having a second child if they get the extra food.  That would make the results .. interesting.

What about the 'winner takes all' strategy that you see many mammals doing?  Where the males fight during the mating session and the alpha gets all the females?  That seems like a pure hawk strategy to me with high risk, but high reward.  The reproductive benefit is huge for the winner.  If you can mate with 20-30 females during a single season, then future seasons don't seem as important.  It's too good of a benefit to the individual, and forces all the males to play the hawk strategy, because unless they win or rape a female, they won't reproduce.  Another interesting thing I've heard was that it is the females that drive evolution, since they do the majority of the 'choosing'.  Then, even though the 'winner takes all' strategy is bad for the majority of the males, it's advantageous to the females to only breed with the top males.  A pure hawk strategy doesn't appear good for a species, but it seems like plenty of them are set up that way and are stable.  Is it that the population stays the same or continues to grow, despite all the fighting? Or is there a duel strategy going on? Like during the mating season, everyone is a hawk, but in the off season everyone is a dove? (I guess I'm thinking of species like deer or elk when I say this, because they seem docile for the majority of the year)

Ok

The Golden Knight card is unlocked upon reaching King Level 14. He is a single-target melee troop who targets grounded units. He has high hitpoints and moderate damage per second. Being a Champion card, he will stay out of the player's card cycle while he is deployed, and only return once he is destroyed. The Golden Knight's ability increases his movement speed when no enemies are nearby, and causes him to dash onto enemies in sequence, similar to the Electro Spirit's attack. He has golden hair and is outfitted in gilded breastplate and gauntlets, as his name implies, and wields an impressively large sword. A Golden Knight card costs 4 Elixir to deploy, and his ability costs an additional 1 Elixir. The Golden Knight has a special ability, accessible from the rightmost side of the screen just above the player's card slots in battle. After a 1 second delay, the Golden Knight activates his "Dashing Dash", gaining a movement speed boost if he is not within 5 tiles of an enemy unit. Once a unit is in range, he dashes to it quickly, then dashes towards any other units within a 5-tile radius (even if the previous unit was not destroyed). His dashes have invulnerability and deal increased damage, like the Bandit. He cannot dash into the same troop per ability use. He will stop dashing after dashing 10 times or if no other valid targets are within range. The ability goes on an 11 second cooldown after the duration ends. The Dashing Dash ability costs 1 Elixir to activate. It is also important to note that his movement speed boost cannot be reset or cancelled by The Log, Zap, Freeze confirmation needed or other things that will normally stop a charge.
Strategy
For the purposes of determining Elixir trades, the Golden Knight and his activated Ability count as 5 Elixir, as the player must play the 4 Elixir Knight and then spend a further 1 on his Ability. While he runs to the tower, use a cheap card like Skeletons to make him dash from the tower into said cheap card. If done correctly, this can be used to cause him to chain dash into the King's Tower and activate it. Because of this, it is not recommended to use his Dashing Dash if there isn't a target. For the reason mentioned above, he can act like an Electro Spirit: Potentially lots of value, but can also be a double edged sword if you accidentally activate the opponent's King Tower. Though this isn't recommended due to the cooldown, the Golden Knight's ability can be used to counter swarms. The Golden Knight is unique in the fact that he can dash onto multiple targets, like a Knight and Tower, and still attack the original target. Because of this, it can be hard to defend against. For example, if a Valkyrie is approaching a tower, the defender will use a Knight to avoid all damage, but if a Golden Knight is approaching and the defender places a Knight close to the tower, it will dash onto the tower, making the defense less valuable. If the player has a unit on the board that they do not want the enemy Golden Knight to reach, they must play more ground units as far away from it as possible to entice the Knight to charge into the more expendable units instead. Due to his low damage output, a glass cannon or mini-tank such as Mini-P.E.K.K.A. or Prince can easily take him out. Once the Golden Knight uses ability, he will not target any units behind him unless they are in range. In other words. The Dashing Dash ability only chains to the troops that the Golden Knight can see.

I guess it is a voluntary overlook to keep the problem simple, but the equations to compute the equilibrium point are not complete.
If d indeed equals 1 - h in a given equation, these value aren't equal to each other in both equations. In the first equation, the considered dove population is the actual population minus one, the one we are considering the odds. Same thing with the hawk population in the second equation.
Since a given individual can't stumble on themself, they are removed from the population in regard to calculating the average outcome. That's why a perfect equilibrium point can't be achieved in that example, only an approximation of it that becomes more balanced the more the populations increase while never reaching perfect balance.
To follow that first example, having both populations equals would still mean that any individual would be slightly more likely to meet an individual of a different kind that their own.
With a hundred of each, each of them would be 49.75% likely to meet something like them and 50.25% likely to meet something different.
With ten of each, each of them would be 47.4% likely to meet something like them and 52.5% likely to meet something different.
With one of each, each of them would have no chance at all to meet something different than themselves and will forcefully meet something different.

Rain: A nuisance for most blobs, slowing them down. Owls get 90% slowed by it and have a 24% win rate. Shoebills get faster and have better damage. Many blobs will hide under trees, but poor owls may die sometimes.

Tree: Hiding places for pigeons and crows. A large "shed" tree with many holes in the middle of the map allows all types of blobs to hide under it. In rain, every type of blob can hide under every tree. Trees also sometimes drop apples which are the same as pellets.

Pond: A small pond near the big tree. Blobs can drink the water to get a better reproduction chance. It is a sleeping ground for shoebills and ducks. Owls sometimes drown and die when walking into the water.

Owl: Eats other blobs but is vulnerable to rain and water. Has a 40% win rate against hawks normally but mostly uses the extremely effective backstab strategy where they go behind an unknowing blob and kill them. Color: White

Seagull: Fast and takes all food it can. It has extremely low HP however. Color: Grey

Crow: Neutral. It shares food with other species. However it is a force to be reckoned with. It can turn excess food into weapons which makes it easier fo fight hostiles. It also lives in packs. When a crow dies and a hostile is seen near the body, crows will be suspicious and if they see a death caused again, they will gang up and kill the hostile. Color: Black

Cuckoo: Steals children from other species and turns them into cuckoos. Its actual children are given to doves, and will need a lot more food to nurture, effectively tiring out the dove and leaving it in a vulnerable situation. It has one glaring weakness: It needs to be sneaky about the children situation. If it gets caught, it will immediately die. They also need to eat more food to survive. Color: Brown

Falcon: Feeds on rammed blobs. It first has to charge up its speed and will speed up every 0.8 seconds. It can ram blobs when it moves half a tile. It increases its ramming power when it accelerates even faster. However, the faster a falcon goes, the harder for it to steer clear of edges. Color: Brownish Grey

Parrot: A slightly aggressive blob. It can claim food piles. Blobs that try to eat a parrot's food pile will get screeched at. Most blobs will get scared, but some will try to fight. However, it shares with food piles that already have a blob eating it. Color: Green

Songbird: A pacifist blob. It chirps and makes calming songs. Songs can break up fights near it. It shares food too. Songs can also attract mates easily, explaining the extreme growth. It is however, the weakest blob and will die at a single hit from predatory blobs. Color: Purple

Shoebill: Protector of the defenseless. When it spots a blob attacking another blob, it will attack the attacking blob. It has massive damage, but will try not to kill the attacker. The attacker will get traumatized and will steer clear of the shoebill for a while. Its only weakness is its slow pace and its slow reproduction.
Color: Blue-grey

Duck: Peacefully swims along ponds and resurfaces to eat. It has low health and is defenseless, but can run away fast. It delivers quite the feast however, as predators can survive AND have two children by eating a duck.
Color: Green, then fades to grey

Let say that this is just like Prisoner's dilemma (5:05)

It's always going to be a non-zero probability for one population to wipe the other one out: doves keep getting matched with hawks and "rolling" the bad roll, and die; hawks with even numbers get matched with hawks and die off;
the greater the food supply the less likely it is for this to occur -- but I'm not sure what that calculation would be exactly (like with the amount of food in his first simulation, is one population likely to die off within a million rounds? a billion? not sure)
what I'm wondering is if both populations have the same odds of getting wiped out... that's an interesting calculation that I'm sure someone's done (but I dunno where to look for it.)

As much as I love the way you did this, it in no way reflects the natural world. Living things reproduce not because they gain excess resorces, but because they are adapted to find a suitable mate. The species then self-selects out those that aren't adapted to find a mate. Unfortunately for many species, being sexually sucessful is not the same thing as being succesful. Humans are so succesful because our females select for success in the collection of resorces, however most mammalian females go into heat, a period of time in which they will mate with any willing male. A good strategy for propogating the species, but not for improving it.

I dont agree with the math here, I think its pretty inaccurate to simulate a "Hawk vs Hawk" scenario in which nothing is gained from fighting for food. If the math is supposed to reflect a realistic environment, its stupid not to realize that animals fight each other all the time for access to food, and said fighting leaves the victor with definitely more energy than none. At the very, very least, the value per "Hawk vs Hawk" outcome should've been a 50% chance of survival for each if not a 50% chance for reproduction. That is WAY more realistic and its how animals act and reproduce in the wild in this exact scenario anyways.
I think making hawk vs hawk be 0,0 ruins the simulation. The probability should be reduced not set to 0

Actually, it’s better to be a dove. As a dove, you always have a chance of survival. As a hawk, you will only survive 2/3 of the time. Because the possible out comes for hawk are:
Hawk Alone: 100% Survival 100% Reproducing
Hawk vs Dove: 100% Survival 50% Reproducing
Hawk vs Hawk: 0% Survival
And the out comes for a dove are,
Dove Alone: 100% Survival 100% Reproducing
Dove vs Dove: 100% Survival
Dove vs Hawk: 50% Survival
Now notice how the Dove always can survive no matter what.

So basically, what I learned from this video is that when a simulation of people who have 2 basic choices (one that shares and one that takes) is implemented, the best option for success is to establish an equilibrium, also specifically known as the Nash Equilibrium (named after John Nash). For instance, if a person uses a hawk strategy (one where they take), it would be much more efficient if you respond with a dove strategy (one where you share). This can also be applied vice-versa. A mathematical function can also be written to represent this function:

Score of doves on average = (score when exposed to other doves * 1) + (score when exposed to hawks*1/2)

Score of hawks on average = (score when exposed to doves * 3/2) + (score when exposed to other hawks*0)
where both score averages have to remain in equilibrium.

When this line is plotted on a graph, the intersection of the line, (AKA the solution for the system) is always held true when doves and hawks maintain a 50% ratio.

What complicates things in the study of advanced game theory though is the versatility of those people, and how some of them can have a different percentage chance of playing either strategy or how some of them may act differently while being exposed to a specific person. But what if the risk of facing both hawks was not as sacrificing? then a specific term known as the prisoner's dilemma comes into play.

One thing I noticed:
With Doves and Hawks, the Population would reach a point in which it wouldn't grow. Doves would be 2 per pair of food, only allowing them to survive and the Hawks would reproduce and kill eachother, reaching an endless loop. Now the way I think is best to assure the permanent prosperity/growth of this species is by adding at least 1 specific blob, different from the others. We'll call him Reproducer and make him yellow. Now let's say the Reproducer only needs half a food to survive and 1 to replicate (it would replicate into a Hawk, Dove or Reproducer). When it met a Hawk, it would have enough to survive and when it met a dove it would have enough to reproduce. Making it able to always live (by having a Dove's behavior, which is taking the half food with a Hawk) and keep the population growing.

1 if neither rats out the other they both get nothing.
2 if one rats out the other and the other stays quiet. The rat gets the full reward.
3 if both rat out each other both become punished.
You can either gamble and rat out the other or gamble and play nice

This is genuinely interesting. The obvious answer at all times is to play dove. Even if you know your opponent is going dove as well. Doing what you'd want others to do for you is the best way to go. It's the same methodology behind murder. The only reason it doesn't happen all the time is because we all have a mutual understanding that the best way to keep ourselves alive is to play our parts and not murder. It's a system of trust. Taking the passive option might seem like the less beneficial option, but it is 100% the most reliable in all situations. The only problem is that wild animals can't see this the way humans can.

The pandemic being the biggest example in recent history of our biggest flaws. Yet with not many better alternatives, or other inability to make meaningful changes regardless of reasoning whether trivial, or logical, we admit a flawed system and at the same time feed it while condemning it. ....I really don't feel like this works because its too oversimplified. If two creatures fought over food in this situation, most are either going to end with one dying or one backing off before things get too serious. The former may or may not die from injury, but the later is almost as good off than if it found the food alone. Actually, it might even be in a better situation depending on the social aspects of the creatures, as establishing dominance would make others more likely to back off.

This game is like split or steal

If, instead of only dove/hawk responses to competition, there was a 2-step process for determining what happens (You decide whether to share the food with your competitor or to steal the food and attempt to scare them away, then if one or both competitors decide to be aggressive you can then choose whether to fight or back down) then the best strategy would be to attempt to share and then if the competitor is aggressive you fight. My reasoning for this is that if you look at the four possible strategies there is a 50% chance that your opponent will also be happy to share, meaning you both survive to the next day, a 25% chance that the opponent tries to scare you but runs away when you stand your ground, giving you a 1/2 chance of reproduction, and if they do decide to fight to the death you have a 50/50 chance of dying or winning the fight, and if you do win then you get the 1.5 food for 50% percent chance of getting to reproduce. Compared to the other strategies this gives you the best chance of surviving the cycle (87.5%) and also the best chance of getting to reproduce (37.5%).

So actually this is all a game of psychology, if everyone played Dove, the population would increase and settle. Eventually some Doves would die without reproducing but this would make room for others to reproduce (there would be more food spare), creating an equilibrium (this also results in the highest possible population as seen in the video). However the most selfish people know that if everybody would play Dove, they could play Hawk, and benefit more for themselves, so then some (let’s say 50%) of the remaining Doves would prefer to save themselves and play Hawk, and then 50% of the new remainder of Doves would switch to Hawk and so on, so on. This continues until the population reaches an equilibrium because people realise that it becomes better to play the minority like it did in the video (when Hawks wasted 100% of there energy fighting).

This would be cool to do with a group of people to make a spectrum of the most selfish of the group to the most selfless. (BTW being 100% selfless is just as bad as being 100% selfish IMHO - the last Dove is just as bad as the first Hawk in their own right). This could also be interpreted as a measurement of stupidity/stubbornness or the like in the group.

The lowest possible population would be with 100% Hawks and the highest with 100% Doves as realised in the video.

This simulation is also almost exactly like the game show “Golden Balls” (so much so that it could have even been an inspiration for the video!) if I am not mistaken, I feel like that is the name of the show that I am taking about. I believe that it is the final round where the last two contestants have to choose to split or steal with the other contestant by picking up a ball with one of the respective words on it (Only they know which one is which, their opponent does not). If both decide to split, they share the prize money, but if one decides to betray and deceive their opponent by selecting the ball that says “steal”, (by using whatever strategy they choose) they will collect all the prize money and their opponent gets nothing. However, if both decide to try their luck and test their morals by stealing, nobody goes home with anything! Do you know that one? Yeah, the video reminds me of it and, of course, the Prisoner’s Dilemma as well.

Simply loved this video, thank you so much for sharing this. Evolution is something that I have been studying in my spare time and thinking about a lot lately, and this made me reflect on some things. In the video, you point out about having other traits that could exist such as conditional strategy and that made me think about two other possible additional situations:
1 - when the hawk is "rational", whenever they find themself disputing the same "food" one of them decides to be a dove. This situation would have an equilibrium of 100% hawk and the same population as the situation you pointed out.
2 - when the dove is "emotional", whenever he finds himself disputing the same "food" with a hawk he would get angry and become a Shawn as well. This situation would make the dove at a disadvantage but in the equilibrium, hawks would disappear so it would be an advantage for the population as a whole since the equilibrium would tend to 100% dove, with a population of individuals bigger than in the situation 1.
With this, I conclude that being "rational" is good for the individual alone, but being "emotional" is good for the population as a whole. It makes me understand why would nature give us the trait of being emotional sometimes. What we usually consider as a defect of human beings may in some situations give out species an advantage.

This reminds me of how wolves behave. Two male wolves in a dominance conflict will growl and growl threatening to fight but usually one will back down and roll over exposing its neck as if to say: yes you could bite my neck and kill me and I could do nothing about it. At that point the dominant wolf could also choose to recruit the submissive wolf to help with hunting. The whole ritual facilitates a conditional strategy. It gives the wolves a chance to analyse what the payoff would look like if they both fought.
Neither wolf wants to fight but neither wolf wants to back down so they have to see which wolf would come off worse in a fight to decide who will back down.

What if there is a blob that always copies their opponent's strategy? So if a competing species is aggressive, they will be aggressive in an attempt to kill off that species. If they have superior numbers, their surviving "copies" (members of the same species) will propagate, leading to more vindictive blobs existing. These blobs would never eradicate the hawks, but they should be able to reduce their number to the point that their own species continues the most (along with the apathetic doves), meaning that the strategy is evolutionarily advantageous.

These population-aware and foresight-driven (or instinctually "copying") blobs clearly disturb the Nash equilibrium. Strategies like this are why I do not like the idea of applying game theory to evolution. Without accounting for hundreds of variables and possible strategies (nature is more creative than we will ever be imo), you will never find the "actual" Nash equilibrium.

Perhaps this is why A Beautiful Mind portrays Nash as a tortured genius who (iirc) believes he has ultimately failed in describing nature.

The hawk v hawk scenario is why army ants don't attack each other. If two swarms of army ants meet they ignore and pass right by. Here's a simulation: Lets say Two Hawks fight, however, one hawk is stronger than the other one, thus keeping some of its energy, while the weaker one barely has any energy left.
We'll call this strength.
If the strength gap is almost none, the weaker one has a chance of winning. If the weaker one wins, the weaker one loses a little less energy than the stronger one. If the stronger one wins, its the stronger one thats keeps a little more energy. If its a medium gap, The stronger one wins, keeping some of its energy white the other hawk barely has energy left. If the gap is high, the stronger one would keep all of its energy, and would have a slim chance of reproducing. while the weaker one gets beaten up, thus having no energy. If the gap is equal, Then both will be weakened equally. Yes, i am not nearly as experienced as Primer, but eh, i think its ok.

This is essentially the concept behind the UK game show "Golden Balls".
During the gameshow there will be a few people who'll play a game to do with opening the balls for money to add to the overall bank and tho knock it down to the last two competitors.
At the end the two remaining players will be sat opposite each other with two balls in front of each of them, one says share and the other says steal. If they both pick share they split the money between them. If they both pick steal they both get nothing. It is a little different though, if one person picks share and the other picks steal, the person who picks share will get nothing and the one who picks steal will get it all. It is similar however and it always made for an interesting watch; it's cool to see that concept broken down further! Great video.

Hey, in advance I am sorry for my English, It is not my native language, but I would like to share some thoughts on the video. I found a problem in the simulations, like: You don't have any social ties in your video simulation, for example, the creature eats two food and reproduces, that's mean that we have a family ties between two creatures, even if they are hawks, they won't fight between, they would split the food for the survival and wait for another day to act. Then, I would like to say about the population, the simulations gives us fixed amount of food, so we have some borders in which creatures will stop reproduce more than some amount of them. Now, imagine these are not just creatures and we are not on the "God" role, these are creatures with their "family name" and they have specific gens(now remember  the main role of the reproducing among the creatures, it is to save you own gens and reproduce them), So now with these specifics of the simulation, we have creatures for example halved (half doves, half hawks). The simulation starts, we will see that doves will be demolished in ~10 days and then we will have the fight between hawks (don't forget about the relative ties), In which they will reach the maximum amount of creatures and will fight for their family tree, in which I personally see reasonable circle of the survival in which particular groups of social active creatures will survive or reproduce. And for the people who will say that the circle between doves is "fair", you aren't playing a real world simulation, in which we have our will to reproduce ourselves with our gens, and in the only dove world, there are no particular personalities, it is just a group of creatures, which are reaching the maximum amount of  them and live till someone's die and only one creature will fill the gap. Thank you for reading, I hope you have got my idea.

Like most mammals, we humans combine two instincts - the instinct to compete and also the instinct to cooperate. Our modern food system is a superb example of this. We Australians grow food on farms which are in competition with each other. However farms may cooperate (not very well) in sharing water from a river such as the Murray-Darling. There are cooperative rules about which herbicides and insecticides can be used on farms and how much fruit pickers from overseas should be paid. Farmers compete via lowering prices in order to sell their produce to supermarkets which also compete in price wars. However there is cooperation around labeling of food so that it agrees with requirements set by the government. Customers cooperate a lot in supermarkets by physically distancing when queueing and in being polite to each other and to shop assistants as they shop. The supermarkets compete against each other by trying to outdo each other with presentation and prices etc but also have to obey certain government laws e.g. re safety and refrigeration. This dance between cooperation and competition seems to work very well.     We also apply it in other areas e.g. playing tennis. Players cooperate around the rules of the game but compete fiercely within those rules. How fiercely they compete depends on a cooperative agreement before the game e.g. let's just have a friendly neighborhood game, or "this is Wimbledon: let's compete to the limit of our abilities."   This ability to weave together cooperation and competition is one of the great strengths of us mammals. However ants and bees do it too. Look at the complexity of a beehive! Fantastic cooperative delegation of duties. However if you threaten their hive, you can feel the competition as they drive you away.  So the above game, Simulating the Evolution of Aggression is interesting but doesn't reflect reality. In practice, communities cooperate together a lot because a harmonious community provides a safe haven for the protection of a pool of genes. There can be some competition within that community. The rich may buy better houses and can buy more food. However allowing some members of the community to be too downtrodden is unwise. Desperately poor community members will turn to crime, making the community less cooperative and thus less safe. A well-run nation like Australia provides a wonderfully cooperative place within which some competition can occur. Survival of the fittest doesn't mean survival of the strongest or the healthiest or most capable. It means the survival of the organism that best fits the environment of which other organisms are a part. Evolution in this sense removes some of the cutthroat competition that some philosophies would place on it. Evolution is about a balance of life forms more than a competition between them.

Fascinating, thank you for sharing. This reminds me very much of the Prisoner's Dilemma and similar ethical and social scenarios we discussed in my one Evolutionary Psychology class. However one thing people often forget when they insist that humans are inherently selfish and that a "survival of the fittest" mentality is the best way to survive is that cooperation has it's benefits too. There is a reason we humans (and other animals) evolved to cooperate with each other. Cooperation not only prevents the mutual demise of both creatures, it also can enhance both organisms' odds of survival and reproduction if, for example, the two organisms worked together to gather and split more food than either organism could have gathered alone. So really, as much as one can argue that violence and aggression is apart of human nature, one could also argue so is altruism and pacifism.

His conclusion about which strategy you should choose is oversimplified.  The "best" strategy depends on what you are trying to optimize for.  If what you care about is the degree to which your opponent does better than you, then you should always choose "hawk".  Because even though you are for sure going to die, at least your opponent will also die - so even scores.  If you aren't "competing" against your opponent, but instead are competing against death - then the strategy outlined in the video is correct.  There are also many intricacies associated with how many iterations/games you will play with this opponent - whether or not you know what strategy your opponent will choose, etc.  This video demonstrates some basic ideas, but to really do interesting/useful things with this, these intricacies and subtleties are important to understand.

The data points are inaccurate. You are biased towards doves. Simple concept really, if an aggressor meets a dove, the aggressor would take ALL the food. If you are going to claim they only take half of the doves food then the agressors meeting each other would not end up with 0 they would each end up with half or one aggressor would net half the spoils.

If two chimps meet in the wild and fight over food, one will either back down or die. The surviving chimp will claim the loot for himself. So the energy spent might be equivalent to half or one food but NOT all the food. If that was the case, territory disputes would cause extinction events.

Words such as "figuring out" and "strategy" imply thought and even purpose. If we're talking about evolution as random, then thought should never implied. Instead words and concepts such as reflex, sense and instinct, better describe what happens in a world devoid of purpose. Whenever we use such words thoughtlessly, we suggest "will" and that suggests "mind," which of course suggests a divine being or at least a conscious being. This really needs to stop or else the scientific community needs to concede that some higher consciousness exists and therefore, some nebulous power might indeed by at the root of existence. I'm not taking sides. just pointing out this frequent error in communicating ideas about godless evolution.

Reduces sustenance to “food units” then allows for food units to be further reduced in the simulation. What’s the point? In reality, the hawk would eat both food units and and scare off or kill the the dove. You altered your model to falsely allow for the survival of the doves by changing your own rules. You do this while using a model that doesn’t account for learned behavior, in that over time, the doves will avoid situations where the hawks will “win” the situation. Over time, life gets easier for the hawks, at least until they start fighting among themselves and the doves turn to communism to increase their chances of survival, despite having insufficiently developed survival instincts.

You also further reveal your bias by making the “good guys” blue and the “bad guys” red, right along political lines, while also promoting the doves as being morally superior in their behavior.

When you don’t get the answers you want by observing the real world, you turn to modeling and simulation...

I just got 2 experiment ideas. Using the hawk and dove, recreate the “tit for tat” strategy. 1. If a Dove and Hawk meet, the dove changes to a Hawk, the Hawk changes into a dove, in which case, they reproduce a dove if they do (revenge). Or 2. If a Dove and Hawk meet, the next time either reproduces, it is the opposite

But it usually doesnt work like this because getting the food is in itself a challenge that is made easier by cooperating. That means that in the long run (from a game theory perspective) the ones that survive are those that learn to work toghether and to ostrasice the agressive ones. Since the latter are doomed to work alone they'll have a greater chance of not getting food, surviving and reproducing. I read this particular theory on a paper not so long ago :)

"Natural Selection is not always good for a species"

It's not good for the original species, but it discriminates between successful and unsuccessful individuals, which'll lead to successful individuals reproducing.

It's kind of flawed to claim that NS is good or bad for a species given that it's just a mathematical perspective on what is going on, rather than what "should" be going on. Adding to that the systems at play in this specific case are not as complicated as those out in the real world and you could also even make the argument that, in a lot of cases, this sort of natural population control that forms out of the balance of hawks and doves is a good thing, given that it makes sure that the population continues to fluctuate and never hits a maximum, which could have consequences over other species.

You can replicate the pairs of food into something more realistic, let's say a cherry pair.
When a Dove or a Hawk gets to a cherry pair by itself, they get 2 food, meaning they will survive AND create a copy of itself.
When two Doves meet at the same cherry pear, they each survive but do not create that copy.
When two Hawks meet at the same cherry pair, they each die.
When a Dove and a Hawk meet, the Dove has a 50/50 chance of surviving and the Hawk survives and has a 50/50 chance of making a copy.

I agree that bring opposite to what you chose gives an equilibrium state. However, I think that dove is always a winning strategy. I am assuming that the goal of my choice is survival of my race (else, why would I prioritize reproducing?). Now, If you choose dove and I choose hawk, my race will increase to just 40 (assuming 100 food and your simulations). Even if we think from the perceptive of surivival alone, the one who will probably kill me is a member from my own race. Why would I want to grow my race (as a hawk)?
Now, If you choose dove and I choose dove too, our race grows to slightly >100. We fully utilize the food. You can only die due to lack of food which will be really rare after some time (each dove will only take 1 food - no reproduction, no death - also, it would be awesome if you can keep track of reproduction/death rates in the video). Here are my mutations:

Green: (codename sparrow) if a green encounters another green, each will take 0.5 food and have a 50% chance of survival. If a green meets a dove, green will take 1 food and the dove will take one. If a green meets a hawk, the hawk will get 1 food and the green will get 1.5 food because the green will eat half a food, but the hawk will fight it and get the other half of the 1st food. The green will then eat the 2nd whole food. Greens eat more the more danger they are in. Greens are very nice creatures, so they feel safe with each other. Hawks are very scary to greens, so they panic eat more. If a green faces a yellow, it will take 1 food. If a green is alone, it will starve.

Yellow: (codename eagle) yellows will take 0.5 food if faced with a green. They will have a 100% chance of survival, as their stomachs function differently. If faced with a dove, it will take 0.5 food but 100% survival. The dove will take 1 food. If faced with a hawk, it will take half a food, and barf up all their food to the hawk. The hawk will get a 100% chance of living and reproducing. The yellow will die. If meeting another yellow, they will find another food pile until they aren’t with a yellow but with another blob.

Well, I noticed a scary trend. When here was equilibrium between Doves and Hawks, sure, the population was steadier and higher as a whole, but it wasn't the highest and most steady of the projections. When you ran just Hawks, the population was tumultuous and never reached highest cap. However, when you ran just Doves, the population had a smooth incline and then steadily capped at the highest total population reached by any projection. So... Now if you adjusted this for an economic model, the equilibrium would be where Hawks earn more than doves based on merit, but not to the point where doves cannot self-sustain. Our current economic system where mega-billionares exist and some people can't afford to eat isn't quite at equilibrium yet.  Obviously it's a lot more complicated than that but game-theory could help us find a more egalitarian model of Capitalism.

A Game Theory

Playing Hawk is high-risk high reward, half of the time when you meet another blob you will have a 50% chance of reproducing if that blob is a Dove, but you will also die if you run into another Hawk. Playing dove is a strategy that guarantees a 50% chance of survival no matter what, and condemns no one to die but maybe yourself. This means that playing Hawk is worse for the survival of a species since the more that a Hawk reproduces, the more Hawk blobs there will be to possibly kill each other and the more likely a Dove blob might die as well. On paper, the role of the Hawk sounds like the best way to go, but it's really the worst option for both your own survival and the survival of the species because while the chance of running into another Hawk seems to cap out at around 40% I would say since only an 80% of the max population seems possible when it consists of Hawks and Doves, and half the population will be Doves and the other half will be Hawks, that 40% chance guarantees that you will die, as opposed to a Dove who has an equal chance of running into a Hawk, who has a 50% chance of dying in that scenario.

Well the real reason we're sympathetic to other humans is mainly so that when the wolves are chasing us through the woods and you trip, you'll mean enough to someone in your tribe for them to stop and help you back up. Its also so you can successfully find a breeding partner. No one wants to breed with someone who's mean to them because 1(if your partner hurts you to the point of incapacity before your child can be born, the likelihood of the child surviving is limited and 2( your child has half your genes and if your partner hurts you for your genes, may hurt the child for the genes you gave it. Now, the reason you'd want your partner to stay while your pregnant is because pregnancy limits your abilities, especially near the end. There's a reason women are provided with maternity leave. In a survival situation, it would increase you and your child's chance of living if there was someone to help you. What does your partner get out of it? Well they pass on their genes through you. Therefore, since the blobs will not receive these advantages, as they are asexual, it is better for them to take food for themselves.

Therefore when there is a increase of the hawks population they have a higher rate of death in there populations. But at the same time if there is more hawks who die, doves increase in population so they are more likely to run into a hawks and die. THIS is why your result self balance.

At first there were only Doves. Then, one kind Dove offered a deal where it would take a chance on surviving on half a food in order to give the other Dove a chance at reproduction. At first, survival of all Doves was perfectly consistent. Through the deal, the Dove receiving the kindness was able to reproduce first and then, later, the kind Dove was able to reproduce as well. Knowing the potential that either it or its friend may die, the kind Dove had initially agreed to help provide for the child of the Dove receiving the kindness if that Dove should die. Eventually, as the kind Dove paradigm became the social norm, one of the Doves who received initial kindness went on to reproduce afterward only to go back and die after returning the kindness to the original kind Dove. The fallen Dove's child grew up quietly resenting the kind Dove who helped raised it and went on to become the first Hawk. Eventually, Hawks came into dominance, only keeping Doves around as a means of survival and profit.
This particular instance of the simulation went on to become commonly referred to as "the human race".

I remember learning Game Theory using the "Prisoner's Dilemma" scenario. Two criminals in policy custody have the option to snitch on each other. In exchange for co-operating, the snitch will get a reduced sentence, whilst the other will take the majority of the blame and get a longer sentence. However, if both try to snitch, they've basically just confessed and will receive the maximum sentence, and if both stay quiet they will get both get greatly shortened sentences.

The point this example made was how individual self-interest can override collective self-interest, and therefore highlights the importance of trust. Logically the two prisoners would both stay quiet and get the best result, but if they cannot trust each other, both will attempt to snitch to save themselves, thus creating the worst possible outcome for both.

Personally I think it's quite an interesting exercise in logic. 😁

Escept that's not how real life works. In real life. Hawks would take 75% if not 100% and your chance of survival would still probably be higher BUT your chances of reproducing when there's a Hawk around would be 0% all the time because they'd simply go to the same spot expecting you to be there and take advantage of it. This is how real animals develop territories. Also your score equaltion is wrong, because it ignores the chances that Doves get food uncontested. That would be the only way for the Doves to reproduce and thus continue existing. Because if they were always at contest the only thing that would matter is if during the 50% chances of survival if they survived at all. In those cases even if they survive if they're only to compete repeatedly for food then there would be no reproduction and thus also the population would eventually become null. Therefore the only reason why you're getting situations where Doves don't vanish entirely is because there are situations where they don't contest Anyone at all.

Is that exactly what a prisoners dilemma is? You describe it a the winning scenario to always be playing H, but in the classic prisoners dilemma two H meeting would cause them both to lose.

Classic prisoners dilemma being that if two D meet, neither D snitches on the other person. If a H and a D meet, then the H wins and the D loses because the H snitches on the D. If two H meet then they will both snitch on each other and both lose. A population consisting of only H would die off in that case.

When the doves and hawks were just introduced, if you ran it for infinite days, sooner or later there would have been only 2 certain outcomes, it would constantly fluctuate until one of those two outcomes happened, first lets look at the situations that cause those outcomes.

Any day that there are equal or less doves than there are hawks, there is a chance that all doves meet a hawk, and every day that there is a par number of hawks there is a chance that all hawks meet other hawks.

If the first situation were all doves meet a hawk comes to happen, all doves are annihilated. (50% was it?, its a certainty given infinite days)

If all doves are annihilated since in this simulation they can only be killed by hawks that means only hawks remain, which means the second situation will eventually happen.

The second situation is all hawks meeting other hawks, thus killing all remaining hawks and wiping out all blob-kind.

However if the second situation happens first, all hawks wipe each other out before the all doves are killed, thus all of blob-kind becomes doves.

Thus only two outcomes are certain, only doves remain, or nothing remains due to hawks killing doves and then eventually outing themselves, a third outcome is impossible unless there had been a time limit.

The 'Prisoner's dilemma' analysis is a bit off. Yes, it would be more profitable for all if all of them could be guaranteed that they would all stay doves forever, and there would never be another hawk. Without that guarantee (which happens if there is ever even one hawk), the hawks take over and replace the doves, and always stay hawks. Staying hawks is the best total strategy, because that guarantee is beyond their control, otherwise they run the risk of being totally replaced.
That built in edge of the hawks is a huge benefit, and far outweighs the bit of extra food as a dove but running the risk of rapid extinction. These rules are picking the best outcomes, you guys aren't always evaluating them fully for all aspects of the outcome. Population max or food max aren't the only factors, but they're all you're evaluating on as to what is 'best'.

it isn't necessarily important that the population is 50/50 hawks and doves, what defines an equilibrium is a point where the change in populations of hawks and doves are both 0, that is, the birth and death rate in both populations cancel each other out. To solve this sort of problem, you need to model it as an autonomous system of differential equations (hopefully linear, for the sake of simplicity), where the specific details regarding the populations interactions make up a matrix that acts on a vector representing the populations, and outputs the vector whose components are the change in each corresponding population. The equilibrium populations will be the represented by the vectors which when multiplied by the matrix representing the populations interactions, output zero vectors.

The prisoners dilemma presumes a state with "hawks" and "doves". But what happens if we exclude hawks from society by putting them in prison... Leaving only doves. The same simulation shows that, as a whole, society becomes stronger.

Nash himself has admitted he was somewhat south of rational when developing this theorem.

And there is precedent for excluding "hawks" who chose selfish, aggressive action over cooperation... I.E. murderers, rapists, thieves, con men, etc.

The prisoner dilemma, as adescription of how things workat afundamental level, is flawed because of these assumptions.

That said... The "grim" outcome described by the prisoners dilemma? That's the world we currently live in. Defecting (aggressive/callous selfishness) is always more advantageous than cooperation. Power doesn't corrupt... Corruption empowers.

Something I've always wondered which probably a few people do as well is how sexual preference might impact a population. For example in a population with binary sexuality reproduction can only be facilitated if the opposing sexes consummate. However introducing homosexuality and bisexuality as genes should produce some really interesting results with far reaching implications for our society.


My prediction is that homosexuality and bisexuality have only become prevalent due to social practices in the past condemning consummation between similar genders, carriers of the homosexual gene were forced to reproduce allowing the gene to spread. However with recent sociological changes now accepting these relationships. We should see that same sex couples are less likely to reproduce and thus the genes should decline in number. Bisexuality however still has a chance of reproduction. So I would love to see a simulation exploring this.

The 2nd AI would always use the strategy of not inserting a coin

Suggestion that i think is great and necessary: Youre modeling these sims as if an organisms goal is to reproduce or survive longer. Ill argue that it isnt. Humans are somewhat special; for whatever reason we have emotions and one of those is happiness. We humans have seratonin, dopamine, oxytocin and  endorphins. We make poor decisions in the long run, in pursuit of short term happiness. For example, humans eat poorly, smoke, drink, do drugs, drive faster, lay around all day, sleep off schedule etc, without thinking "hey, these poor choices are making my lifespan shorten, and may affect my offspring." Instead, we are focused on feeding these chemicals which our brain processes as happy or sad. It would be neat to introduce multiple food sources, some which increase happiness, and some which increase lifespan. Giving each food pellet a "nutrition" and "taste" variable, with corresponding colors/patterns would allow blobs to detect and eat food, while some blobs think about future health, and some think about current happiness. What do you think?

My biggest Problem here is that there are some flaws/problems here with the survivale rate.
If i remember correctly you said they need "1 Food/Full Part" to survive. So giving them a 50% chance to survive when they have only 50% to eat is kinda cheating. But even if we ignore that and say this is ok: By the next time a "Dove" gets only to eat 50% of 1 Survival Food the Chances shouldnt be 50% again.
This Dove is already weakend from the last Foodsharing and this should be considered for the next Foodsharing.
My proposal would be everytime a Dove gets only 50% of the needed Survival Food their chance of Survival gets reduced by 50% of their privious "%".
Example: The first time a Dove survives with 50% against a Hawk and after that that Dove faces a Hawk again and now has only a 25% to survive, because its already weakend. If it survives again and faces a Hawk again it survival chances are reduced to 12.5% and so far.
I know this is much rather a prisoner dilemma, but your example of food and survival is for me kinda "bad".

So both are necessary... Hawks keep a Dove population in check, so food never runs out, but they also keep themselves in check. Doves make sure there IS a stable population. But who said you get to choose which you want to be first?  There is an inherent bias built into the game, even if the choice is made via a random process.  Once the primary choice is made (regardless of the method by which the choice was made or assigned), the game eventually becomes a function of the initial condition.  These initial-condition-contingent games are probabilistically predictable to the point of the end result being almost deterministic, and only rarely one might encounter an X factor outcome.

In regards to strategy when you know what the other person will choose, even though it is always optimal to let the opponent win if they're choosing hawk, studies have shown that most people will still choose hawk to punish the opponent, at least if the dove reward is proportionally small enough. This has been demonstrated in an exercise called the "ultimatum game" and holds true even if the receiver can make up to 3 months' wages from accepting a deal where their opponent receives much more. Human conceptions of fairness (and other instincts) lead us to very suboptimal decisions. This also demonstrates that pure game theory is a terrible model of actual human interactions.

Your variables are nonsense with regards to game theory, the dominant strategy has too much dumb "risk", the hawks should have 50% of surviving to the next day when they meet whilst when a Dove meets a Hawk, the Dove should have 0% chance of surviving whilst the hawk WILL reproduce. That makes sense in terms of how Game Theory was made up. Co-operating doesn't give you a lot of benefit, dominant strategy absolutely demolishes your opponent and gets you extreme gains.

So if the rules are changed to realistic numbers, if you add hawks to the mix, they'll dominate entirely, and if you add any dove, it will just get wrecked instantly.

Just saw your matrix, and it is of-course nonsense. You're greatly over-valuing co-operation, whereas it's punished in the original game theory, you're undervaluing the incentive for dominant-strategy. More specifically and the largest problem is that "if you know I will be a hawk, your strategy is to be a dove" doesn't make sense AT ALL, from the perspective of game theory. Being a dove whilst the other one is a hawk is the worst strategy, in original numbers:

Being a dove whilst the other person is a hawk: you get -3, hawk gets 0

Being a hawk whilst the other person is a hawk: you get -2, hawk gets -2

Therefore for the combined welfare, the best strategy is to co-operate = -1 for each, but for an individual, the dominant (hawk) strategy is ALWAYS the best: 0 for you.

But aggression doesn't only increase the chance of reproduction. It sharpens the traits of a population and evolves biological tools (weapons, essentially) that make dealing with conflict much easier. Also, you didn't allow hawks to actively kill. If they did, and both evolved traits (for example, doves would evolve a higher reproduction rate, or lower metabolism allowing them to go for longer with less food) and if killing also constituted a food unit, I think the population size would fluctuate and even possibly enable one side to gain an incredible advantage against another. Maybe also include a herd variable which allows doves to be less prone to dying against hawks if they are surrounded by more doves, and give hawks a similar chance of dying in battle when surrounded by a herd of doves. Also you could variate the kill chance of hawks depending on their food consumption. Would be cool too to give  each species a compounding chance to evolve a favorable trait with each generation. idk how heavy that would be computationally, but I bet it would be interesting. I bet you'd get something similar to Africa. Small group of apex predators and herds that rely on numbers and herbivorous consumption and high reproduction rate to survive, and then maybe a scavenger class that can kill herbivores but not the apex. Whew all the possibilities.

I paused the video at 9:43 and got the same answer using a different method.
If D=H
and D=d*1+h*1/2
and H=d*(3/2)+h*0
Then we could substitute both sides and get
d*1+h*1/2=d*(3/2)+h*0
Simplify (remembering PEMDAS/Order of operations)
1d+0.5h=1.5d
Then, subtract 1d from both sides to get
0.5h=0.5d
And multiply each side by 0.5^-1 a.k.a. 2 and we get
h=d
So, if d and h are equal to one another, and
1=d+h
they both must add up to 1 to be in equilibrium,
then both numbers must be 0.5 or 1/2 in order

to correctly satisfy both equations.

A suggestion for an extension of the model: escalating revenge. That is, a blob is a dove with doves, but with hawks it aims to maximize the competition cost or at least retaliate with more damage than it received. Allow the competition cost to be negative (scorched earth, destroying the gain + health damage). Add some random misunderstandings when 2 such blobs meet and one accidentally sees another as a hawk. Compare and juxtapose this to "honorable hawks" that aim to minimize competition cost. That is, suppose hawks differ in how much competition cost they create in a hawk/hawk encounter, and there are 2 possible outcomes: in one they impose different costs on each other (and end up with different gains), in another the cost averages between them.

The premise that this is a demonstration against "survival of the fittest" is false. This is a good demonstration, but it has nothing to do with this theory. More aggressive does not mean more likely to survive, it is self limiting. Most adaptations that are advantageous don't have such a strong limitation. A room with more hawks will more likely kill more hawks. A more fit species does not kill itself off. A more fit species doesn't necessarily kill anything to be more fit. It might just fit its ecosystem better.

So... Basically, here's a summary of human behaviour (based on some of the results found in this video):

The majority of the population are hawks. It's much less of a gamble, because you stand to benefit in every situation. (Hawks overpower doves, and tie with other hawks) However, doves can only pray they encounter other doves (but if this happens, it's the best outcome overall). Hawks can easily, and will easily take advantage of the doves around them. All the hawks are too scared to become doves because they're taking too many risks. And many doves become hawks after they see how beneficial it is (with how many dang hawks there are!!!)

So basically, everyone's a terrible person. And if you try to be nice, you end up worse off.
It's a balancing act, like our ecosystems. When one grows too large, they die off and leave room for the other to grow.
There’s only 1 possible outcome I forsee happening in this simulation: (I know it’s not the popular thing but...); there’s just a single hawk remaining.

My biggest takeaway is how much higher the population threshold is when you eliminate the hawk mentality. Sure your individual success (reproduction) is lower, but with an individual failure rate (death) of zero, the population reaches it's success ceiling, which is dependent solely upon the amount of resources available.


Basically a population is more successful as a whole when all parties involved are doves. Just one surviving hawk eliminates potential for max capacity due to the introduction of a PvP failure rate.


Moral of the story: Teamwork

While its an interesting simulation to say the least it's hard to say that it in anyway is practical in any scenario other than that of a computer simulation and a brain exercise. As a "hawk"-like creature in any real scenario will rarely challenge another "hawk" unless there is a large enough benefit in doing so. Secondly "hawks" that do challenge other "hawks" do have a chance to end up both dying but by in large the outcome will still have a winner. For example take a cheetah vs a lion, both aggressive hunters that have similar diets, if they were to be pit against each its rather unlikely that they would both die in actuality its much more likely that one will win and result in having 2 food, 1 for the energy it burn and 1 for survival, as well as less hawks to compete with in the future "hawks" aren't really the kind to just share 1/2 and 1/2 while fighting, instead it becomes an all or nothing deal. Also most hawks wouldn't share with the doves, doves would generally have to find their own source of food and avoid the hawks. Again great brain exercise and interesting concept but not really applicable in most cases for anything more than that.

Basically you teached the key concept behind a poker game. When you are facing an opponent playing GTO (game theory optimal) strategy, you can't do nothing but play GTO as well. Then you both are in Nash Equilibrium, neither both of you can unilaterally increase yours EV (expected value = money). But when someone is playing with unbalanced strategies (let's suppose always going "dove") you should deviate from equilibrium as well and play Hawk everytime if you want to maximally exploit him until your opponent notices your strategy, too.

This is an interesting example of game theory, but I think this is a poor model of the evolution of aggression, due to how simplified it had to be. One issue you can't simulate is that each creature is potential food, and that each creature must convince a mate to reproduce with them, which often requires (sometimes violent) competition. Food is often scarce, creatures are of varying sizes, even among the same species depending on their age, health and how well fed they are. Aggression, as far as I can tell is the primordial default strategy, and more social behaviour only develops when necessary. You also made the assumption that maximizing population size was the good outcome, where having powerful individuals compose a slower growing population can be a stable strategy over a vast amount of time.

Some things to consider at 9:00 when you do the calculation of the Dove and Hawk score.
First, you have to state that the are equal amounts of doves and hawks compared to the food, which in the simulation never happened. The formula would look like D = (fraction doves meetable) * dove food score + (fraction hawks meetable) * hawk food score + (fraction food leftover ) * 2 . This, however, would still not suffice since the picking of food by a creature is not random, but fixed to some degree because it is not possible for three blobs to show up at one food source.
Second, when you say the population is 90% dove and 10% hawk, a dove does not have 90% chance of meeting another dove but rather (total amount of doves -1)/(total amount of creatures -1)
Which is not 90% in this case

You value reproduction far too much when considering equilibrium. If reproducing at least once is your ultimate individual goal, then your work here is pretty good, but here's something to consider.


If the population is at "equilibrium" (50% doves, 50% hawks) then the best play is to always play dove.
A dove has a 50% chance of encountering a hawk, in which case it receives .5 food and survives 50% of the time
A dove has a 50% chance of encountering another dove, where it will 100% survive.
A dove in equilibrium has a 75% chance to survive a random encounter. There's a 0% chance of reproduction if you encounter another player, but because the presence of hawks prevents food saturation, you still have a low% chance of finding unattended food and securing a 100% reproduction cycle.


A hawk has a 50% chance of encountering another dove, in which case it will definitely survive.
But there's also a 50% chance it encounters another hawk and instantly dies.
A hawk in equilibrium dies 50% of the time he meets another player, and the only advantage is a 25% reproduction chance (50% when meeting doves, 0% against other hawks) which isn't significantly higher than the likelihood of just finding unattended food. The important note here is that once you fail your 50% check and die, your chance of reproducing in the future is also 0%. It's in your best interest (as someone who wants to stay in the game) to not play hawk, but it's also in your best interest as someone who's interested in reproducing as many times within your time in the game as possible to not play hawk, because doing so increases the odds of your run ending prematurely.


The safest strategy is to play dove at 50% hawk/dove population, because at this point in time, more hawks will die than doves, meaning there will soon be a population where more than 50% of the population remains dove. This is the point at which switching to hawks to repopulate becomes advantageous, as your likelihood of survival increases quite a bit. You should only play hawk at food equilibrium if you're certain it's the last iteration of the game. This remains true until the point where playing hawk becomes always safer than dove (and the prisoner's dilemma kicks in)

This is an interesting simulation but I think if you wanted to consider the aspect of aggression seriously you'd look into the Hawks being carnivorous, or maybe omnivorous, in which they can choose to consume the food pellets or use more energy to consume a dove for more points and make choices like that.

I don't think it's really simulating aggression if both classes of creature consumes the same food or doesn't have a choice to make a decisions in a predatory manner, it's simply basic sharing principles and not exactly representative of real world mechanics.

I think you should try it with a class of creature which can consume doves and food pellets, but not hawks, a class that can consume doves only, and a class that can consume doves and hawks. Also I know this is a RNG based simulation, but aggression is not a purely random concept, as a truly aggressive entity will stalk and prey.

If you were to expand this even further, allow each class to store fat, that is, take all pellets or prey objects and store extra energy to either become stronger/higher defense, make more moves, or take a turn off, while making them a greater target on the field, in which perhaps predatorial creatures might choose to work together to take them on and split the reward of stored energy, like wolves might do.

Perhaps there is a dove that is on a winning streak and has 10x the energy stored up and decides to give it another chance on the playing field, they might attract the attention of two top tier predators who could then take it down for 5 food points each and sit out the next round, like hibernation. Doves might be able to protect themselves by sharing food pellets and not allowing a space for a hawk/predator to attack. Rounds could be increased to 2 or 3 moves to allow for leftover food as a result of predation to be consumed.

It's an interesting concept with lots of room for ideas and growth and simulation, just like real world ecology, and if simulated on a larger scale it could provide an interesting animal system for open world video games, in which all animal types are actively making decisions to attack or hide each other and the player character/npcs based on their hunger and food points.

The model is flawed. In trying to understand the emergence of aggression in this way you posit that 2 hawks hurt each other, end up sharing the food but spend the entirety of their energy, thus failing to reproduce. This ends up messing with your simulations, as that's the least likely thing to happen. It would have been more meaningful to leave food collection to chance, leading to the survival of one or both of the participants. Then incorporate a different element, being % chance of death in the fight for collection of the food. Otherwise the simulation is flawed and fails to tell us anything worthwhile in accounting for the evolution of aggression. It's always interesting to me how mathematicians play with these inconsequential models, developing them with equations thinking that they've discovered something only to have incorrect assumptions. The whole premise was wrong from the get go.
