Reminds me of the situation with sex ratios. For many animals, if you want a population to be as reproductively effective as possible, you want many females per male. The male's role in reproduction is pretty quick, so you don't need very many. But the animal's genes determine the ratio of sexes of its offspring. If you're an animal in a population that's 90% female, and you're deciding what type of offspring to give birth to, you'll want to give birth to males, since their expected reproductive success is way, way higher. And the opposite applies in the 90% male population. So it balances - if the population moves away from 50:50, that creates an evolutionary pressure to produce more offspring of whichever sex is in the minority. So you end up with 50:50 sex ratios even though the species as a whole would be better off with an imbalance.

I get that you are trying to do the prisoner's dilemma, but the best solution to that is to narc before your cohort can. The best solution to survival, however, is cooperation and mutuality. Personally, I'd rather kill the person who plays as a hawk, even at the cost of my own survival because, if I know that player's strategy and that we will face off, I can eliminate a potential threat to the group survival. This is the problem of applying game theory; social animals have a natural drive to protect one another and math can't easily predict the impact of animal drives on intelligent species . So, no matter the odds, the best possible plan to max potential for the species  is to murder the murderers before they get to the rest of the community, then the doves can live their best lives. As humans, we must imagine the world without us in it. Death is only the end if you think the story is about you. We can no longer afford to tolerate hawks

Note that if you added another variable (max lifespan in amount of turns) the initial simulation of doves only would have wiped itself out because once saturation is reached all doves will encounter another dove at the food and will share said food and thus not reproduce and thus the entire species will be wiped out because while everybody gets to eat nobody gets to reproduce and eventually the entire species will age and die.. or at least there's a significant chance of that taking place if there are no non-ageing related ways to die..

So that's basically a perfect example of why 'peace' doesn't work and strife is necessary for survival.

I'm imagining a simulation with 3 species.
First the rules... food clusters have 1, 2, 3, or 4 food pellets with them. An Herbivore is worth 2 food pellets when consumed by a Carnivore. Each creature will keep hunting for food until time runs out or until it is full (except the parasites). If a creature has 1 food pellet of food at the end of the day, it survives and it's food pellets is reduced by 1. If it has more than 2 then at the beginning of the next day, it reproduces and it's food pellets are depleted by 2. Food pellet locations are set, so locations aren't merely coordinates on a grid, rather they are locations like how the spaces on a chessboard are set locations, regardless of where IN that space your chess-piece is actually set. Creatures that die at the end of the day die AT the location they were last at, even if they begin the day at the edge of the board and move inward. Not every space will have food, which is important to help regulate the third species.

Species-1 is a strict herbivore, it goes to 1, 2, or 3 (depending on random number) of clusters until it is "full".
Species-2 is a strict carnivore, it goes to 1, 2, or 3 clusters of food but doesn't eat any of them. Instead it looks for herbivores to eat, eating them and taking 2 food-pellets plus one more if the food pellets that herbivore had were greater than 2 at the time it died.
Species 3 is a strange one, it is a parasite that latches on to a food pellet and to any herbivore that eats that pellet. The parasite eats one food-pellet from it's host at the end of the day (before deciding if the host has enough food to survive). If the host gets eaten (herbivore/carnivore) then the parasite has a 50% chance of moving to the carnivore. If the carnivore starves to death then the parasite lingers there for a day, gaining a food pellet from it's fallen host's body. If food pellets appear at that space on the next turn, then the parasite infests it. A food pellet cluster with a parasite will automatically feed that parasite one pellet per day and will not disappear at the end of the day. The parasite dies if it is on a space with no food and isn't picked up by a host by the end of the day.

Admittedly, this is going to be ridiculously complicated. Presumably we'd need to start with Species-1, then introduce Species-2 and let them achieve equilibrium. Finally we'd need to introduce Species-3 into the mix and see how they interact. How many spaces produce food and how much food is produces is also a variable to consider, but I think these are lesser variables and suspect that it can be resolved in this way. Each space generates a random number 1-8 and then subtracts 4, if this results in a negative number then it resolves at zero instead. This makes roughly half of the spaces barren each turn. The spaces with food will be fairly evenly distributed between 1, 2, 3, and 4 food pellets on each space.

for those to lazy to draw a graf:
Equilibrium: D = H
D = d * 1 + h* 1/2
H = d * 3/2 + h* 0
d + h = 1
h = 1 - d
D = H
d * 1 + (1 - d)* 1/2 = d * 3/2 + (1 - d)* 0
d + 1/2 - 1/2d = 3/2d
d + 1/2 = 4/2d
d + 1/2 = 2/1d
1/2 = d
d = 1/2
1 - d = h
1 - 1/2 = h = 1/2
meaning a 50/50 dove/hawl population

“Moral law is an invention of mankind for the disenfranchisement of the powerful in favor of the weak. Historical law subverts it at every turn. A moral view can never be proven right or wrong by any ultimate test. A man falling dead in a duel is not thought thereby to be proven in error as to his views. His very involvement in such a trial gives evidence of a new and broader view. The willingness of the principals to forgo further argument as the triviality which it in fact is and to petition directly the chambers of the historical absolute clearly indicates of how little moment are the opinions and of what great moment the divergences thereof. For the argument is indeed trivial, but not so the separate wills thereby made manifest. Man's vanity may well approach the infinite in capacity but his knowledge remains imperfect and howevermuch he comes to value his judgments ultimately he must submit them before a higher court. Here there can be no special pleading. Here are considerations of equity and rectitude and moral right rendered void and without warrant and here are the views of the litigants despised. Decisions of life and death, of what shall be and what shall not, beggar all question of right. In elections of these magnitudes are all lesser ones subsumed, moral, spiritual, natural.”
There is a sort of online simulator called The Evolution of Trust by Nicky Case which lets you replicate exactly these situations.

Sometimes I get distracted by a video and after a while of hopping from one to another end up anoyed at myself for not doing something else, even if by that point I've forgotten what "something else" is- this, however, isn't one of those times: I stumbled into this video, loved it, binged through the rest of the channel, then came back and am pretty pleased with my desition to watch this in the first place. The same happened to me when I found the channel “Kurzgesagt – In a Nutshell”, back in 2016 and “MinuteEarth” in 2018.




These are all very beautiful, relevant, informative “hidden gems” in a sea of “seemingly opulent, but not quite so, overly exposed gems”, if I may, though what sticks out to me, is that YouTube only thought of recommending these to me in such intervals after I’d already been watching animal and science-heavy content for a few years by then.

The sudden realization of this had me confused, but then (literally as I wrote this, no joke) I remembered what that “something else” was and how it’s somehow related to this, if thematically, and that is that our society not just the YT algorithm is very much selfish and incapable of delaying instant gratification, in this case, instant gratification taking the from of around 20ish minute meme and/or slap-stick and/or fake drama and/or nostalgia fests with little to no extra substance and the selfishness being the extremely punishing results of not sticking to that formula and trying something else.




It’s a bit sad to me, but it doesn’t affect me too much since I was apparently born with dead hopes
for our species, and what little that thought does do to me is taken away by the fact that I found this gem today, hopefully, I’ll keep getting lucky with these, but I don’t think so.

Every time i watch more of these videos I am getting more astounded.
First off, each time he runs a new similation, he first has to make up rules.
These rules are the drivers for the actions and reactions these creatures take based on what is presented in their simulated world.

So, before anything happens, HE MUST make rules.
He must submit these "simple blobs" to someting that didnt exist before, something he imagined and enforced upon his simulation.

The creator needs to add something to the creation in order to achieve the desired action; observing how the simulation will run its course.

What these videos show, is that this simulation will not run if there is no force behind it, pushing imagination into the realm of "virtual reality" and observing the effects.
The question remains, how can nothing, create something.

The narrator is showing something in the generated reality of his choice, which is controlled by the rules he sets, and the characteristics he imbued the creatures with.
It is, something, creating something.

In the end, these videos are all cute and all, however they also ignore the reasons for how creatures in the real world would obtain these traits to begin with, without an outside force imbue-ing them with traits prior to running the simulation.

One thing you should do is make a case of carnivores and herbivores. You could start off with “plants” and blobs to eat them. The plants could have a replication chance, making the simulation less artificial. Maybe the plants could have mutations to if they give more food when eaten, or if they can replicate more. This would show how changes in the environment can change the population. Afterwards you can add a carnivore. Carnivores will attack other blobs and will have a chance to kill the blob and eat them. A carnivore’s mutations could be things like speed and aggression, fluctuating the chance of killing a blob. A carnivore gets a total of 2 pieces of food, while a normal plant has a total of 1 piece of food. Herbivores could also mutate and evolve to fight back against the carnivores or have a higher speed to run away from their predators. This can show a food chain, showing how each creatures need eachother to survive. The herbivores need plants to survive, the carnivores need blobs to survive, and you could even say the plants need the carnivores because they cut down the herbivore population and help them survive. Afterwards, omnivores could be added, having them eat both blob and plant. Kind of reminds me of playing The Isle. Different but related problem.

With the Isle, you know the server population, but not how many herbivores or carnivores there are. Generally, a lower server population makes it more advantageous to play an herbivore, since your chance of coming across another player is low, which is an advantage in that there is both less competition for plant life and also fewer players with an in game mechanical reason to want to kill you. However, as server population increases, it becomes more and more viable to play a carnivore, again for to closely related reasons: there is more competition for plant life (if other players are playing herbivores) and there is also a greater chance you will run across another player to eat (or get the chance to scavenge a carcass of another player).

It would be interesting to calculate at what points it becomes more viable to play carnivore than herbivore or vice versa, but for that you would need to know the plant count on the map.

To break out of the prisoner’s dilemma, one party has to have a strategy for forgiving, to play dove when their opponent plays hawk. This allows the other party to switch strategies and play dove if they too have the forgiveness strategy, and this keeps both parties with a high survival and reproductive rate. However, a player may then switch strategies and play hawk to steal resources from the doves and have a chance to do better than their opponent, at the risk of running into another party playing hawk. It would be interesting to see how the blobs do with a Tit For Tat strategy.

I think it's worth noting how the expected outcome of an encounter, like in the table at 5:00, corresponds with the probability that a creature survives, and the probability that it reproduces. For example, an expected encounter outcome of 3/2 means that the creature will, on average, turn into 3/2 creatures. That could mean that the creature will certainly survive and it has a 50% chance of reproducing, as you showed, but it could also mean that the creature has a 3/4 chance of surviving, and that if it survives, it will certainly reproduce. In general, the expected outcome can be calculated by taking d * 0 + s * 1 + r * 2, where d = the probability that the creature dies, s = the probability that the creature survives but doesn't reproduce, and r = the probability that the creature reproduces, where d + s + r = 1.

7:00 (In an infinite time frame one of the two groups will always die out.)

Which of the groups is more likely to die out?

(Probably doves as hawks can only die out if there are only 2 haws left that face each other at the end which is way less likely than the last dove missing its 50/50.
If that simplified reasoning is right, then the hawk strategy is "better." In a state of competition.

But if we now value the probability of one or the other dying out to the "quality" of the world these two scenarios leave behind in pure population size the doves win.

As there will be no absolute answer but if we just calculate this is raw numbers (risk over outcome) haws still probably have an edge if you only look at them.

Except we evaluate the quality after an infinite time frame where the absolute number of organisms will always be higher in a World where the doves win.

If you look at the whole system though, both species being alive is better than the hawks winning for both populations (as there is effectively more food)

Making doves the "most objective" (in my line of reasoning without speciesism) better/more necessary strategy.

Assuming more life=good.

(Assuming the food source is truly a stable unchangeable factor.)
